items.title: US reports first severe case of bird flu in a person | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Officials in California have declared an emergency over the rapid spread of bird flu in livestock. The first case of severe bird flu in a person has also been confirmed in Louisiana.
The H5N1 virus is widespread in wild birds and can easily spread to commercial poultry and cattle. It has been detected in hundreds of dairy cattle herds this year and dozens of people nationwide. Health officials say it's generally only a concern for animals, and most infected people had mild cases. 

Chapters
00:00 California declares bird flu emergency
00:36 Lena Sun, health reporter with The Washington Post
05:02 Peter Chin-Hong, Professor of Medicine at UC San Francisco

#birdflu #california #h5n1

items.title: Blinken urges UN Security Council to act on Sudan | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
The United States has announced it will deliver some 200 Million dollars in humanitarian aid to Sudan, where a civil war has killed tens of thousands of people and triggered the world's largest displacement crisis.
The 200 Million dollar package is in addition to over 2 Billion dollars the US has sent to Sudan since April 2023, when fighting broke out between the Sudanese army and the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary group. 

Chapters
00:00 UN Security Council discusses Sudan
00:36 Shayna Lewis, Sudan Specialist from PAEMA

items.title: How influential is Musk among the far right in Germany? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Elon Musk, who's also a close adviser to Donald Trump, posted on X that the far-right Alternative for Germany is the only party that can save Germany. The AFD is at odds with the country's mainstream parties, because of its hardline anti-immigrant and anti-European Union stances. It's also under observation by German law enforcement because parts of the party are suspected of seeking to undermine Germany's democratic order.

items.title: How Assadâ€™s fall is shaking up Germanyâ€™s migration debate | Berlin Briefing podcast
items.author: DW News
items.content:
In this episode, we dive into the complexities surrounding the future of Syrians in Germany. After the Assad regime was toppled, the German government decided to suspend asylum proceedings for Syrian citizens. The debate in Germany has been heating up since then- not least because political parties are attempting to stress their differences even more than usual: We properly entered election campaign period this week, after all, with German chancellor Olaf Scholz losing the requested vote of confidence in parliament, paving the way for elections on February 23rd. Host Nina Haase speaks to DW's Michaela KÃ¼fner and migration expert Raphael Bossong from SWP think tank about where Germany stands-almost ten years after Angela Merkel said "we can do this" about taking in more than a million people.

Key discussions include:

The potential impact on the German labor market if a large number of Syrians were to return to Syria
The varying statuses of Syrians in Germany and the implications of these differences
The evolution of German conservativesâ€™ migration policies since Angela Merkel
The role of migration and asylum policies in the current German election campaign

ðŸ”” Subscribe to the DW Berlin Briefing podcast for more insightful analysis on global affairs. We'll have a new episode out every week. If you can't wait that long - do subscribe to our Berlin Briefing newsletter: https://www.dw.com/en/berlinbriefing/... 

#BerlinBriefing #TransatlanticRelations #EuropeanSecurity 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Will these former Islamist rebels run Syria as a secular state? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
The first US diplomats to visit Syria since the fall of the Assad regime have arrived in Damascus. They're holding talks with the rebels who now form the de-facto government, and who the US and other states still classify as a terrorist organization. 
It's a sign of transition that's also reflected across the country, where some members of former President Assad's military are being integrated into the new order. They've been told to hand over their weapons or face prosecution. And many say they're happy to do so.

Chapters
00:00 Former Syrian soldiers hand over their weapons
04:25 Mohamad Chreyteh, DW correspondent
08:48 Burcu Ozcelik, Senior Research Fellow for Middle East Security atRoyal United Services Institute

items.title: China builds a new $3.5bn megaport in Peru: Why is it facing pushback? | Transforming Business
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Chinaâ€™s new $3.5bn megaport in Peru strengthens the trade relationship between the two countries and gives it direct access to Latin Americaâ€™s valuable minerals, ensuring its own strategic growth and control over the global mineral supply chain. But the megaport has been described as environmentally destructive, at a time when the maritime industry is honing its green efforts.

items.content:

items.title: German payment card for asylum seekers sparks criticism | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Caption: Germany's roll out of a payment card to distribute funds to asylum seekers has been met with criticism. The new system launched this year and was devised to make it harder for cardholders to send money outside of Germany. But detractors of the new program say it also makes spending money on necessities here in Germany more difficult.

items.title: Traumatized and living in fear: Gaza's children fight for survival | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Doctors in Gaza say at least thirty Palestinians, including children, have been killed in the latest Israeli airstrikes. Mediators are still working to secure a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas. For children in Gaza, a deal can't come soon enough. Most have already lost family, friends and their homes. And with schools closed, they're also losing their education.
